Description: Mould-made disc-shaped scaraboid in glazed composition; slightly domed and plain back with more or less straight sides; underside decorated with represention of a falcon to right and a squatting god or godddess holding a papyrifom sceptre to left; motif possibly stamped rather than incised; pierced lengthwise; glaze very worn off (said to be unbaked and unglazed on the EEF distribution list) but scant remains of pale turquoise glaze on base; yellowish cream core; broken through middle and mended.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The association of a squatting deity and a falcon is a known theme on scaraboids produced at the “Scarab Factory” (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no. 127; on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). This scaraboid belongs to a type that was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93, 98, 101, 106-107, type XXVIII A, subtype 214-219b, see especially A216 for this piece). On the distribution list, the sketch accompanying this piece shows a squatting deity holding a ankh sign. It seems though that the deity holds a wadj sceptre. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 127)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 98 and 101, Type XXVIII A216)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.030) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4907 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
